newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chip stocks weighed down by IBM loss.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chip stocks weighed down by IBM loss.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks fell Wednesday, spurred by an earnings-driven sell-off in the shares of International Business Machines Corp., but other technology stocks continued to move higher.
At 1:25 p.m. EST, the 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average was off 46.95 points at 6,836.95, pulling back after chalking up its 10th record close of the year on Tuesday.
In the broader market, declining issues beat advances by a 13-11 margin on moderate volume of 336 million shares.
The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with high-tech issues, rose 7.54 points to 1,384.51. The American Stock Exchange index was up 0.13 at 590.07.
IBM, which was down 8-1/4 at 159-3/4, accounted for about half of the Dow's drop.

"IBM is 34 points of the Dow's drop," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd. "But Intel and Microsoft are putting on a spectacular show. The deployment of funds into these two first tier names continues unabated."
Microsoft Corp. added 2-3/8 to 97-3/8 while Intel Corp. rallied 1-7/16 to 149-1/2.
The blue-chip market received little help from a soft bond market. The benchmark 30-year Treasury was steady with the yield unchanged at 6.79 percent.
Bleier said strength in tech stocks and the narrow decline in the broader market despite the sell-off in blue chips pointed to the resilience of the overall market.

"Many people will view the drop in IBM as a buying opportunity," he said. "If we had a more skittish market, the IBM sell-off would have resulted in an across the board rout. But this market just appears to be bullet-proof."
IBM tumbled as analysts cut their earnings estimates for the world's largest computer maker after it posted lower profit margins and disappointing hardware revenues in the fourth quarter.

"On a bigger scale, though, the techs are far from done," said Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Co. "Most of the tech earnings have met or exceeded earnings expectations, and by and large this sector of the market remains healthy."
Alfred Goldman, technical analyst at A.G. Edwards & Sons, said that if one subtracted IBM from the equation in Wednesday's trading, the market would be a big yawn.
"Without IBM we would be having a normal little pause to refresh on the Dow. I don't see a serious downside risk to this market at this point," he said.
IBM was not the day's only loser among technology stocks. Computer Associates International fell three to 43 after the the company also reported disappointing results.
Compaq Computer Corp. was up 5-5/8 at 83-7/8 on upbeat profits for the latest quarter.
